datafield.subfield: Egypt, called in the country Missir, by J.B. D'Anville, of the Royal Academy of Belles Lettres, & of that of Sciences of Petersburg.
Graphical scale bar: 9.5 cm. = 80 English statute miles.

9 graphical scale bars with legend as follows: 'Roman Miles rated at 756 Toises. Grecian Stades eight of which correspond to a Roman Mile. Grecian Miles and common in Turkey rated at 7 Stades. Arabian Miles rated at 1000 Toises. Stades of antient [sic] Egypt rated at 51 Toises. Egyptian Schoeni composed of 60 Stades. Horary or Travelling Leagues for the Caravans rated at 1900 Toises. French Leagues of 3000 Geometrical Paces or 2500 Toises. English Statute Miles rated at 1500 Toises.'
66 x 40.5 cm. on sheet 76 x 51 cm.
On map: 'MDCCLXV [1765]. Published 4th July 1799, by John Stockdale, Piccadilly.'
Originally bound and folded into the book:
Observations on the manners and customs of the Egyptians : the overflowing of the Nile and its effects / with remarks on the plague, and other subjects. By John Antes.
Original map in French, published in 1771, on The David Rumsey Historical Map Collection website.

In Sep. 2007 the map was removed from the book [Observations on the manners and customs of the Egyptians : the overflowing of the Nile and its effects / with remarks on the plague, and other subjects. By John Antes], in the process of restoration, and cleaned from fungus. Map is now stored separately with map collection.
